scenes.on_screen_action: Quick jump-cut intro. Split-screen: left a flashy neural-net montage (glossy, blurred), right a clean CLIPS terminal. Distracted Boyfriend meme overlay in the center: boyfriend looking at CLIPS side, girlfriend labeled 'Neural nets = hype'. Bold red hook text pops in with a smash zoom. Whoosh SFX.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Tired of black‑box AI? Want practical, readable rules? Meet CLIPS — rule‑based programming that actually explains itself. 30 seconds. Go.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Want practical AI? Meet CLIPS — 30s
Neural nets = hype    CLIPS = readable rules
Hook: One assert — watch rules fire.
Follow for: 'deftemplates in 30s'

scenes.on_screen_action: Fast morph into an Expanding Brain meme with four panels stacking: top labeled 'Neural nets: fuzzy', bottom 'CLIPS: explicit rules'. Animated arrows connect to bullet icons: rule-based, object-oriented, procedural. Short list slides in on the right with icons.
scenes.dialogue_vo: CLIPS is multiparadigm: rule‑based, object‑oriented, and procedural. It uses forward‑chaining — start with facts, let rules derive new facts.
scenes.on_screen_text:
CLIPS: multiparadigm
- Rule‑based
- Object‑oriented
- Procedural
Forward‑chaining: facts → rules → new facts

scenes.on_screen_action: Drake Hotline Bling meme split: top 'No: Black‑box models' (Drake rejecting), bottom 'Yes: Rule‑based CLIPS' (Drake approving). Overlay a terminal window on the approving side showing a deftemplate snippet. Camera zoom on code.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Core pieces: facts, deftemplates (fact shapes), and rules (if → then). Let's write a deftemplate and assert a fact — watch the system think.
scenes.on_screen_text:
No: Black‑box models
Yes: Rule‑based CLIPS
Show: deftemplate + assert
Code:
(deftemplate person
  (slot name)
  (slot age))

scenes.on_screen_action: Terminal fullscreen. Type animation: defining a deftemplate, then hitting enter. Quick highlight of slots. Text pointer: 'Deftemplate in 20s — see a match'. Small tip bubble.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Deftemplates define the structure of facts — the slots you're allowed. Think of them as schemas for facts.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Deftemplate in 20s — see a match
Code:
(deftemplate person
  (slot name)
  (slot age))
Tip: slots = named fields for facts

scenes.on_screen_action: Surprised Pikachu meme pops up as a single assert is entered. Terminal types: (assert (person (name John) (age 30))). Then run (facts) to show fact-list. Pop & ping SFX. Small 'watch facts' debug button appears.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Assert adds a fact to the fact list. One assert — rules might match and the agenda fills up. Watch this.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Assert example:
(assert (person (name John) (age 30)))
Then:
(facts)
Watch tip: (watch facts)
Hook: One assert — watch rules fire.

scenes.on_screen_action: Split: left shows rule anatomy infographic (Header / LHS conditional elements / RHS actions). Right shows typing of a simple rule into the terminal with syntax highlight. Use Expanding Brain snippet for 'Rules: explicit if → then'.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Rules have three parts: header, LHS patterns to match, and RHS actions to run when matched. Here's a tiny greet rule.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Rule anatomy: Header | LHS (conditions) | RHS (actions)
Example:
(defrule greet
  (person (name ?n))
  =>
  (printout t "Hello " ?n crlf))

scenes.on_screen_action: Animated flow: Facts → pattern matching (magnifying glass) → Activated rules drop onto an 'Agenda' panel with ping sounds. Two Buttons meme appears: Button A 'Rewrite model', Button B 'Encode rules (CLIPS)' — finger slams B. Agenda UI shows rule 'greet' queued.
scenes.dialogue_vo: When facts match a rule's LHS, that rule is activated and put on the agenda. You're encoding logic — not re‑training anything.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Flow: Facts → Match → Agenda
Agenda shows activated rules
Two Buttons: Pick B — encode rules
Tip: (watch activations) to see agenda updates

scenes.on_screen_action: Terminal: user types (run). Whoosh SFX as the rule populates and fires. Show output: Hello John printed. Animated diagram shows 'facts → agenda → fired rules'. Overlay: 'CLIPS in 30s: assert → run → fire'.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Type (run) and the engine fires rules from the agenda. Facts cause rules to activate, run executes them — instant transparency.
scenes.on_screen_text:
(run)
Output: Hello John
Summary: facts → agenda → fire
SFX cues: pop, whoosh, ping

scenes.on_screen_action: Terminal shows deffacts block creation. Then (reset) is typed and you see the deffacts asserted. Side-by-side show (retract 1) and (modify 1 (age 31)) commands being used with trash and edit SFX. Small CTA badge 'Debug rules fast: use watch — no cap.'
scenes.dialogue_vo: Use deffacts to preload a set of facts. Reset clears the environment and asserts those deffacts. Retract and modify change the fact list at runtime.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Deffacts + Reset:
(deffacts init
  (person (name Alice) (age 25)))
Commands:
(reset)    ; asserts deffacts
(retract 1) ; remove fact id 1
(modify 1 (age 31)) ; change slots
Debug tip: (watch facts) (watch rules)

scenes.on_screen_action: Quick code montage showing pattern matching with variables, then a multifield example. Use bright callouts for '?n' and '$?rest'. Appealing animation showing wildcard matching a list. Text bubble: 'Deftemplate in 20s — variables & wildcards.'
scenes.dialogue_vo: Variables bind slot values in patterns. Use ?var to capture single fields and $?multi for multi‑field matches. To ignore values, bind to a name you won't use.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Variables & Wildcards
- Single: ?n captures one field
- Multifield: $?rest captures many fields
Example:
(person (name ?n) (hobbies $?hobbies))
Tip: bind to ?ignore if you don't need the value

scenes.on_screen_action: Debugger-style screen with live watch output. Commands typed: (watch facts) (watch rules) (watch activations). Asserts and retracts stream logs in a console panel. Surprised Pikachu reappears as a rule chain causes many firings. Quick overlay: 'One assert — watch rules fire.'
scenes.dialogue_vo: Debug like a pro: (watch facts), (watch rules), and (watch activations) print what's asserted, retracted, and which rules fire. Saves you hours of mystery bugs.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Debug commands:
(watch facts)
(watch rules)
(watch activations)
Live output → see facts and rule firings
Hook: Debug rules fast: use watch — no cap.

scenes.on_screen_action: Rapid recap montage: clips of deftemplate, assert, agenda, run, watch, reset. Expanding Brain meme list appears with final level 'Watch: visualize fact changes'. End card with a big CTA button, social icons, and 'Gist/link in bio'. Upbeat ping sound.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Recap: deftemplate → assert facts → rules match → agenda → run → rules fire. Use deffacts and reset for initial knowledge, and watch to debug. CLIPS: explicit, fast, debuggable.
scenes.on_screen_text:
CLIPS in 30s: assert → run → fire
Quick checklist:
1) (deftemplate ...)
2) (assert ...)
3) (run)
4) (watch facts/rules)
5) (reset) to reload deffacts
CTA: Save this clip — follow for 'deftemplates in 30s' 
Gist/link in bio • More CLIPS tricks next

scenes.scene_name: Scene 12 — Recap montage & CTA end card
video_asset: Rapid recap montage clips: deftemplate, assert, agenda, run, watch, reset
Expanding Brain final level graphic 'Watch: visualize fact changes'
End card with big CTA button, social icons, 'Gist/link in bio' overlay

voice_timing.text: Want to build an expert system? Meet CLIPS — a tiny rule-engine that can outsmart a full ML stack for the right problems. 30 seconds, let's go!
CLIPS is multiparadigm — rule-based, object-oriented, and procedural. So you get clean rules instead of nested if-else spaghetti.
Forward-chaining: start with facts, apply rules, derive new facts. One assert can trigger a chain reaction. No cap.
Facts are the data chunks CLIPS reasons about. Deftemplates define the structure — like a schema for facts.
Add facts with assert. CLIPS assigns a fact id and puts it in the fact-list.
Group initial knowledge with deffacts, then use reset to assert them automatically. Use watch to see facts as they appear or disappear.
Rules have a header, LHS patterns that match facts, and RHS actions that run when activated. You bind variables with ? and can even bind a fact-address to modify it.
When patterns match, rules activate and go to the agenda. Run executes the agenda and fires rules in order — you can inspect the agenda first.
Modify or remove facts at runtime. Retract deletes a fact, modify changes slots. Simple commands, huge power.
Facts + Rules = magic. Use watch to debug fact assertions/retractions and watch the state change live.
Quick demo: deffacts, reset to load them, assert one more fact, peek the agenda, run — watch rules fire and facts change.

TL;DR: CLIPS = facts + deftemplates + rules. Assert facts, rules activate to the agenda, run to fire, modify/retract to change state — and watch to debug. Try it — one assert can change everything. Follow for more CLIPS micro-demos!
